content.description: P1 5.4 -- Start at right end of ledge before it drops into Chapel Pond (main wall), at a series of left leaning cracks.  Follow these cracks for a bit until you can get onto the arete, then climb the arete.  Near the top step left and continue up to fixed anchor at tree.
content.protection: I used (2) tricams on the route.  There are pockets that didn't seem to accept any type of gear due to being flared.  Some cracks and a couple nut placements.  Overall I felt the gear was mediocre and there was a bit of runout between pieces.
content.location: Start at the right end of the bottom ledge (left face).

content.description: Face climb, avoiding the arete to the right and groove to the left.
content.protection: Very little pro unless you wander off route.  Ideal top rope climb after leading one of the other routes.
content.location: Start 15 feet left of the arete at a featured wall.

content.description: P1 5.5 PG -- Follow cracks to left leaning crack, follow this to its end then move right and up less protectible face to the tree anchor.
content.protection: Thin at the top.  Probably better to just lead Shipton's and top rope China Groove.
content.location: 25 feet uphill from ledge at base of the arete, at a blocky groove.

content.description:
Just right of Tilman's Arete along the shore of Chapel Pond.

 ___UPDATE 2020___ There are bolts and chains at the top.

 ___UPDATE May 2014___ Due to large rack fall the tree previously used for an anchor has been severely damaged. The next closest tree capable of supporting rappelling is several feet back from the edge of the cliff. Knot the rope ends and stay left at the bottom of the wall/corner to ensure your rope reaches the base.

 Rappel is on the left/main wall into a small corner/gully, NOT over the water on the unclimbed outer wall. 60m is sufficient.
